title: Designing an Online Course: Where Do I Start?
text:
As data and computation continue to reshape disciplines across the university, faculty are increasingly called upon to integrate code, collaboration, and scalable infrastructure into their teaching. Yet, despite this growing demand, instructors often lack structured guidance on how to develop and maintain reproducible instructional materials across tools, platforms, and modalities.
Teach Reproducibly is a faculty-facing resource developed by the Metropolitan College, in partnership with BU ELIVE Services and BU Virtual, to support instructors in building robust, version-controlled, and scalable course content for use in Boston University’s Blackboard Ultra environment.
This book provides practical guidance for instructors teaching in data-rich and computation-heavy domains — including analytics, computer science, statistics, engineering, public health, and beyond — who are committed to developing high-quality, maintainable instructional workflows.

title: Building a Quarto Microsite Structure
text:
Create a blank folder on your computer.
Make sure that this folder is not on a cloud sharing service if you plan to use it wit Github.
Open the folder in VS Code or Antigravity IDE.
open terminal on IDE either by selecting Terminal -> New Terminal or by using keyboard shortcut Ctrl +
You can create a Quarto website by running the following command:

quarto create project website .
This automatically ask users::
? Title (website) » example project
and will generate the following structure:
name/
  ├── _quarto.yml
  ├── index.qmd
  └── styles.css   (depending on template)
Now open the folder in VS Code, RStudio, or any preferred editor.


In the root of the project, create the standard site pages:
index.qmd
syllabus.qmd
deliverables.qmd
schedule.qmd
todo.qmd          # Instructor-only checklist
Purpose of Each Page

index.qmd → Course homepage
syllabus.qmd → Course policies
deliverables.qmd → Assignments & grading
schedule.qmd → Module or weekly timeline
todo.qmd → Instructor checklists





In your project folder, add:
M0/
M1/
M2/
M3/
M4/
M5/
M6/
M7/
M8/
Nine modules total.




For example, inside M1/ create:
M1_LN1.qmd        # Lecture Note 1
M1_LN2.qmd        # Lecture Note 2
M1_P1.qmd         # Presentation 1
M1_P2.qmd         # Presentation 2
M1_T1.qmd         # Tutorial 1
M1_T2.qmd         # Tutorial 2
M1_Lab1.qmd       # Lab 1
M1_Lab2.qmd       # Lab 2
M1_A.qmd          # Assignment
M1_Proj.qmd       # Project step
M1_highlights.qmd # Summary landing page
M1L1_figures/
M1L2_figures/
Copy this structure for every module from 0–8, adjusting the naming prefix.




Replace the default file created by Quarto CLI with a course-oriented version:
project:
  type: website

website:
  title: "Course Name"
  navbar:
    left:
      - href: index.qmd
        text: Home
      - href: syllabus.qmd
        text: Syllabus
      - href: deliverables.qmd
        text: Deliverables
      - href: schedule.qmd
        text: Schedule
      - text: Modules
        menu:
          - text: Module 0
            href: M0/M0_highlights.qmd
          - text: Module 1
            href: M1/M1_highlights.qmd
          - text: Module 2
            href: M2/M2_highlights.qmd
          - text: Module 3
            href: M3/M3_highlights.qmd
          - text: Module 4
            href: M4/M4_highlights.qmd
          - text: Module 5
            href: M5/M5_highlights.qmd
          - text: Module 6
            href: M6/M6_highlights.qmd
          - text: Module 7
            href: M7/M7_highlights.qmd
          - text: Module 8
            href: M8/M8_highlights.qmd

title: Tool Setup
text:
Welcome to Module 0. Before beginning analytics, Quarto development, and programming workflows, students must install and configure:

Git & GitHub
Antigravity (Google’s VS Code–based IDE)
Quarto
Python
R
Pandoc
Graphviz

This module ensures every student has:

a working IDE
version control correctly configured
environments set up
the ability to edit, preview, and publish Quarto content
a GitHub Pages site (username.github.io)
experience with pull → edit → commit → push workflows

title: Tool Setup
text:
Install Git
Git is the version control system used throughout this course.
Mac:
brew install git
Windows: Download and install: https://git-scm.com/download/win
Linux:
sudo apt update && sudo apt install git -y

title: Tool Setup
text:
Install GitHub CLI (gh)
This tool connects your IDE (Antigravity) with GitHub.
Check installation:
gh --version
Installation: https://cli.github.com/

title: Tool Setup
text:
Install Quarto
Used to build websites, slides, notebooks, and documents.
Download: https://quarto.org/docs/download/

title: Tool Setup
text:
Install Pandoc
Required for Quarto PDF and DOCX output.
Mac:
brew install pandoc
Linux:
sudo apt install pandoc -y

title: Tool Setup
text:
Install Graphviz
Required for diagrams, ML visualizations, and flowcharts.
Mac:
brew install graphviz
Linux:
sudo apt install graphviz -y

title: Tool Setup
text:
Install Python 3.12
Download: https://www.python.org/downloads/
Check: Add Python to PATH.
Linux:
sudo apt install python3 python3-pip -y

Install R
Download: https://cran.r-project.org/

title: Tool Setup
text:
Set Git Username and Email
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"

title: Tool Setup
text:
Generate SSH Key
ssh-keygen -t ed25519
Press Enter to accept defaults.

title: Tool Setup
text:
Add Public Key to GitHub
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
Copy and paste it into GitHub: https://github.com/settings/keys

title: Tool Setup
text:
Test SSH Authentication
ssh -T git@github.com
Expected output:
Hi <username>! You've successfully authenticated.

title: Tool Setup
text:
Create Repository on GitHub
Go to: https://github.com/new
Repository name:
yourusername.github.io
Select:

Public
Add README
Add .gitignore (Python or R)

title: Tool Setup
text:
Clone the Repository Locally
git clone git@github.com:yourusername/yourusername.github.io.git
cd yourusername.github.io

title: Tool Setup
text:
Make Your First File
echo "Welcome to my GitHub website!" >> index.md

title: Tool Setup
text:
Commit Your Change
git add .
git commit -m "Initial website content"

title: Tool Setup
text:
Push to GitHub
git push origin main

title: Tool Setup
text:
Pull Changes to Confirm Workflow
git pull

Create Python Virtual Environment
python3 -m venv .venv
Activate:
Mac/Linux:
source .venv/bin/activate
Windows:
.venv\Scripts\activate
Install common packages:
pip install numpy pandas jupyter matplotlib quarto

Initialize R Environment
Open R and run:
install.packages("renv")
renv::init()
install.packages(c("tidyverse", "knitr", "rmarkdown"))
renv::snapshot()

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text: In the realm of modern education, especially within data-centric disciplines, the ability to manage and collaborate on code is paramount. Git and GitHub serve as foundational tools that facilitate version control, collaborative development, and reproducible research. This chapter aims to introduce these tools, providing educators with the skills necessary to integrate them into their teaching workflows.

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
What is Version Control?
Version control is a system that records changes to a file or set of files over time, enabling you to recall specific versions later. In educational settings, this allows instructors to:([arxiv.org][2])

Track the evolution of course materials.
Collaborate with colleagues on curriculum development.
Revert to previous versions of teaching resources when necessary.([docs.github.com][3])

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
section: Git: A Distributed Version Control System
text:
Git: A Distributed Version Control System
Git is a distributed version control system that allows multiple contributors to work on a project simultaneously without interfering with each other’s work. Each contributor has a complete copy of the repository, including its history, on their local machine. This setup enhances collaboration and ensures data integrity.([docs.github.com][4])

For more information, refer to the official Git documentation: About Git.([docs.github.com][4])

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
GitHub: A Platform for Collaboration
GitHub is a cloud-based platform that hosts Git repositories, providing tools for collaboration, code review, and project management. In an educational context, GitHub can be used to:

Distribute assignments and course materials.
Facilitate student collaboration on projects.
Manage feedback and revisions efficiently.([docs.github.com][5], [en.wikipedia.org][6])


Learn more about GitHub here: About GitHub.([docs.github.com][7])

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
Installing Git
To begin using Git, you need to install it on your local machine.

Windows: Download the installer from Git for Windows and follow the setup instructions.
macOS: Install Git using Homebrew:
brew install git
Linux: Use your distribution’s package manager. For example, on Ubuntu:
sudo apt-get install git


Detailed installation instructions can be found here: Set up Git.([docs.github.com][8])

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
Configuring Git
After installation, configure your Git username and email address. These details will be associated with your commits.
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your_email@bu.edu"
To verify your configuration:
git config --list

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
section: Creating a New Repository on GitHub
text:
Creating a New Repository on GitHub

Log in to your GitHub account.
Click on the “+” icon in the top-right corner and select “New repository”.
Provide a repository name, e.g., teaching-materials.
Optionally, add a description.
Choose the repository’s visibility (public or private).
Initialize the repository with a README file.
Click “Create repository”.([docs.github.com][1])


For a step-by-step guide, refer to: Quickstart for repositories.([docs.github.com][1])

title: Introduction to Git and GitHub
text:
Cloning the Repository Locally
To work on your repository locally:

Navigate to your repository on GitHub.
Click on the “Code” button and copy the URL.
Open your terminal and run:
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/teaching-materials.git
Navigate into the cloned directory:
cd teaching-materials
